clinical_study.brief_title: The Influence of Amitriptyline on Learning in a Visual Discrimination Task
clinical_study.official_title: The Influence of Amitriptyline (Amitriptylin-CT 25 mg®) on Learning in a Visual Discrimination Task (Karni-Sagi-paradigm)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether 75 mg amitriptyline affect the sleep dependent consolidation of procedural memory (visual discrimination task, Karni-Sagi-paradigm).

detailed_description.textblock: Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep is considered critical to the consolidation of procedural memory - the memory of skills and habits. Many antidepressants strongly suppress REM sleep, however, and procedural memory consolidation has been shown to be impaired in depressed patients on antidepressant therapy. As a result, it is important to determine whether antidepressive therapy can lead to amnestic impairment. We thus investigate the effects of the anticholinergic antidepressant amitriptyline on sleep-dependent memory consolidation in 32 healthy men in a double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized parallel-group study.

primary_outcome.measure: changes in the visual discrimination task's perception threshold
primary_outcome.time_frame: The visual discrimination task's perception treshold is assessed before sleep (day 10 at 6 pm) and after sleep (day 11 at 6 pm).
primary_outcome.description: Improvement in this task is defined as a decrease in the perception threshold between training and retrieval testing.

secondary_outcome.measure: amount of rapid eye movement (REM) sleep (sleep period time percentage)

intervention.description: amitriptyline 25 mg at 9:30 pm, day 10, and 50 mg at 1:30 am, day 11
placebo(white 8 mm Lichtenstein®) at 9:30 pm, day 10, and at 1:30 am, day 11

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- male gender
- age 18 through 40 years
- ability to communicate effectively in German
Exclusion Criteria:
- shift work within the past 24 months
- any sleep disorder as measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index
- irregular sleep/wake patterns or extreme chronotype as measured by the Morningness-Eveningness Questionnaire
- history of any neurologic or psychiatric disorders
- regular medication intake within the past four weeks
- contraindications for amitriptyline
- abnormal electrocardiogram (ECG)
